thread.title: Glencore swoops on Sirius' nickel

author: Peter Ker
title: Glencore swoops on Sirius' nickel
text:
Glencore chief executive Ivan Glasenberg has shored up nickel supply from Sirius' Nova deposit in WA.
Glencore's financial troubles have not prevented the Swiss giant from swooping on the remaining offtake from Sirius Resources' Nova mine in WA.
In a deal that completes the offtake process for Sirius for the time being, Glencore will buy half of the nickel and copper concentrate produced at Nova for the first three years of the mine.
The agreement comes after BHP Billiton agreed in March to buy half of the first three years' concentrate from Nova, and Trafigura agreed to buy copper concentrate from the mine.
Both BHP and Glencore have nickel operations within a few hundred kilometres of the Nova mine but while the concentrate bound for BHP will go into its Nickel West smelter at Kalgoorlie, Sirius said the concentrate bought by Glencore would be shipped overseas out of either Esperance or Geraldton ports.
Advertisement Nova is not expected to come into production until late 2016, and the fact that 100 per cent of production for the first three years has already been sold amid a weak nickel market is a tribute to the expected high quality of the Sirius concentrate.
The mine is expected to reach full capacity, at 1.5 million tonnes ayear, by the December quarter of 2017.
Sirius managing director Mark Bennett said he was pleased to have completed the offtake process.
Sirius is the subject of a takeover bid from Independence Group, and Glencore's offtake deal with Sirius will do nothing to quell rumours of a rival bid emerging.
Glencore was interested in the Nickel West sale process that BHP shelved last year, although the downturn in commodity prices has reduced its ability to get deals done.
Takeover meeting coming up A scheme meeting relating to the Independence takeover offer will be held on September 3.
Patersons Securities analyst Simon Tonkin said it was possible that Glencore could emerge with a rival bid for Sirius but it was also possible that the offtake deal had satisfied the Swiss company's desires.
"I wouldn't discount the possibility that Glencore could make a rival bid considering they have circa $10 billion in undrawn credit facilities and cash," he said.
"But if they do, it would be on the last day or two before the [Sirius] scheme meeting on 3 September. An all-cash bid would be very attractive to SIR shareholders and the value of both companies [SIR/IGO] have reduced since the initial bid."
Nickel has been one of the worst performing commodities of 2015, with prices sliding by 29 per cent since January 1.
The equation is even worse on a 15 month time-frame, during which nickel prices have halved to the current price around $US10,625 a tonne.
Falls in all commodities have taken their toll on Glencore's finances, and there were reports earlier this week that activist shareholder Harris Associates had bought more than 1 per cent of Glencore shares.
By Tuesday morning Harris Associates stake was revealed to be 4.5 per cent, making it the fourth largest shareholder in Glencore.
But chief investment officer for Harris Associates David Herro said the investment was designed to secure long-term value while prices were low, rather than being an "activist" play.
Glencore will announce full year profit results on Wednesday.
Sirius shares were 8 cents lower at $2.61 on Tuesday while Independence shares were 10 cents lower at $3.16.
